name: Mass-energy equivalence
details: In physics, mass energy equivalence is the concept that the mass of an object or system is a measure of its energy content.

name: Newton's law of universal gravitation
details: Newton's law of universal gravitation states that any two bodies in the universe attract each other with a force that is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them.

name: Centripetal Force
details: The magnitude of the centripetal force on an object of mass m moving at tangential speed v along a path with radius of curvature r.

name: Angular Acceleration
details: The acceleration of a particle moving on a curved path as a function of time.

name: Velocity in Circular Orbits
details: The relative velocity in a circular orbit.

name: Kinetic Energy of Rigid Bodies
details: In physics, the kinetic energy of an object is the energy which it possesses due to its motion. It is defined as the work needed to accelerate a body of a given mass from rest to its stated velocity.

name: Gravitational Potentia Energy
rep: U = PE = mgh = -{G M m \over r}
details: Gravitational energy is the potential energy associated with gravitational force, as work is required to elevate objects against Earth's gravity.

name: Time-dependent Schrödinger equation (general)
details: The most general form is the time-dependent Schrödinger equation, which gives a description of a system evolving with time.

name: Time-dependent Schrödinger equation (single non-relativistic particle)
details: Schrödinger equation for a single particle moving in an electric field.

name: Time-independent Schrödinger equation (general)
details: The time-independent Schrödinger equation predicts that wave functions can form standing waves, called stationary states (also called 'orbitals', as in atomic orbitals or molecular orbitals).

name: Time-independent Schrödinger equation (single non-relativistic particle)
details: Time-independent Schrödinger equation for a single particle moving in an electric field.

name: Tangential Velocity
details: Tangential speed (or tangential velocity) is the linear speed of something moving along a circular path.

name: Linear Impulse
details: In classical mechanics, impulse (symbolized by J or Imp) is the change in linear momentum of a body.

name: Angular Impulse
details: In classical mechanics, impulse (symbolized by J or Imp) is the change in angular momentum of a body.

name: Linear Momentum
details: In classical mechanics, linear momentum or translational momentum (pl. momenta; SI unit kg m/s, or equivalently, N s) is the product of the mass and velocity of an object.

name: Angular Momentum
rep: L = I \omega = R \times p = R \times mv
details: In physics, angular momentum, moment of momentum, or rotational momentum is a measure of the amount of rotation an object has, taking into account its mass, shape and speed.

name: Force
rep: \vec F = {d \vec p \over d t} = m {d \vec v \over dt} = m \vec a
details: In physics, a force is any influence that causes an object to undergo a certain change, either concerning its movement, direction, or geometrical construction.

name: Pythagorean theorem
details: In mathematics, the Pythagorean theorem—or Pythagoras' theorem—is a relation in Euclidean geometry among the three sides of a right triangle. It states that the square of the hypotenuse (the side opposite the right angle) is equal to the sum of the squares of the other two sides.

name: Area of Circle (Disk)
details: The area of a disk, more commonly called the area of a circle, of radius r is equal to πr2. Here the symbol π (Greek letter pi) denotes the constant ratio of the circumference of a circle to its diameter or of the area of a circle to the square of its radius.

name: Electric Power
details: Electric power is the rate at which electric energy is transferred by an electric circuit. The SI unit of power is the watt, one joule per second. Electric power is usually produced by electric generators, but can also be supplied by sources such as electric batteries.

name: Ohm's Law
details: Ohm's law states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the potential difference across the two points. Introducing the constant of proportionality, the resistance, one arrives at the usual mathematical equation that describes this relationship.

name: Young's Modulus
rep: E = { \sigma \over \epsilon} = {F / A_0 \over \Delta L / L_0} = {F L_0 \over A_0 \Delta L}
details: Young's modulus, also known as the Tensile modulus or elastic modulus, is a measure of the stiffness of an elastic isotropic material and is a quantity used to characterize materials. It is defined as the ratio of the stress along an axis over the strain along that axis in the range of stress in which Hooke's law holds.[1] In solid mechanics, the slope of the stress–strain curve at any point is called the tangent modulus. The tangent modulus of the initial, linear portion of a stress–strain curve is called Young's modulus.
